## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 153, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 278, 905, 333]]<|/det|>
0606/12 February/March 2018 2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 425, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 437, 375]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Electronic calculator  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 446]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 504, 461]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 380, 490]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 282, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 828, 545]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 593, 559]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 603, 574]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 606, 600]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 599, 759, 614]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 614, 437, 629]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 80.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 89]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 164, 561, 182]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 195, 240, 212]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 225, 383, 244]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\),  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 243, 572, 282]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 312, 228, 329]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 333, 754, 371]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n},\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 494, 415]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 481, 594, 498]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 513, 156, 530]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 541, 584, 610]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \mathrm{e}^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 640, 242, 657]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 663, 590, 696]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 715, 593, 770]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 905, 109]]<|/det|>
The remainder obtained when the polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x) = x^{3} + ax^{2} - 3x + b\) is divided by \(x + 3\) is twice the remainder obtained when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \(x - 2\). Given also that \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divisible by \(x + 1\), find the value of \(a\) and of \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 428, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = 4 + 5\sin 3x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 143, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 100, 230, 120]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 322, 141, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 918, 343]]<|/det|>
Hence find the equation of the tangent to the curve \(y = 4 + 5\sin 3x\) at the point where \(x = \frac{\pi}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 346, 920, 365]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 447, 91]]<|/det|>
Do not use a calculator in this question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 114, 144, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 109, 228, 133]]<|/det|>
Simplify

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 108, 887, 134]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{(3 + 2\sqrt{5})(6 - 2\sqrt{5})}{(4 - \sqrt{5})}\), giving your answer in the form \(a + b\sqrt{5}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 138, 228, 157]]<|/det|>
integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 138, 920, 157]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 358, 146, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 357, 480, 377]]<|/det|>
In this part, all lengths are in centimetres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[256, 389, 781, 502]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 856, 542]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the triangle \(ABC\) with \(AB = 6 - 2\sqrt{3}\) and \(BC = 6 + 2\sqrt{3}\). Given that

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 548, 798, 575]]<|/det|>
\(\cos ABC = -\frac{1}{2}\), find the length of \(AC\) in the form \(c\sqrt{d}\), where \(c\) and \(d\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 97, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 379, 102]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = \frac{\ln(4x^2 - 1)}{x + 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 143, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 520, 133]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(x\) for which \(y\) is not defined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 114, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 348, 141, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 343, 230, 375]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 349, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 702, 141, 722]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 700, 920, 722]]<|/det|>
Hence find the approximate increase in \(y\) when \(x\) increases from 2 to \(2 + h\), where \(h\) is small. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The first 3 terms in the expansion of \((2 + ax)^{n}\) are equal to \(1024 - 1280x + bx^{2}\), where \(n, a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 143, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 121, 440, 140]]<|/det|>
Find the value of each of \(n, a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 574, 141, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 567, 747, 600]]<|/det|>
Hence find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(2 + ax\right)^n \left(x - \frac{1}{x}\right)^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 574, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 88, 707, 272]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 920, 326]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the quadrilateral \(OABC\) such that \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\), \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OC} = \mathbf{c}\). It is given that \(AM:MC = 2:1\) and \(OM:MB = 3:2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 143, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 384, 356]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{AC}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{c}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 338, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 470, 143, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 390, 489]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OM}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{c}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 471, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 688, 143, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 688, 346, 707]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OM}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 689, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 73, 141, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 379, 91]]<|/det|>
Find \(5\mathbf{a} + 10\mathbf{c}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 291, 141, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 289, 697, 310]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{AB}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{c}\), giving your answer in its simplest form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 291, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 94, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 144, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 77, 583, 109]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) for which \(\det \left(\begin{array}{ll}2a & 1\\ 4a & a \end{array}\right) = 6 - 3a.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 82, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 144, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 359, 507, 396]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\mathbf{B} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ -3 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 399, 180, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 399, 272, 418]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathbf{A}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 400, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 516, 180, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 516, 532, 536]]<|/det|>
Hence find the matrix \(\mathbf{C}\) such that \(\mathbf{AC} = \mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 516, 920, 536]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 819, 143, 838]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 819, 527, 838]]<|/det|>
Find the \(2 \times 2\) matrix \(\mathbf{D}\) such that \(4\mathbf{D} + 3\mathbf{I} = \mathbf{O}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 820, 920, 838]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 898, 122]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\), moving in a straight line, passes through a fixed point \(O\) at time \(t = 0\) s. At time \(t\) s after leaving \(O\), the displacement of the particle is \(x\) m and its velocity is \(v\) ms\(^{- 1}\), where \(v = 12\mathrm{e}^{2t} - 48t, t \geqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 144, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 311, 154]]<|/det|>
Find \(x\) in terms of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 403, 143, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 403, 574, 422]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(t\) when the acceleration of \(P\) is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 403, 920, 422]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 740, 141, 758]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 740, 562, 758]]<|/det|>
Find the velocity of \(P\) when the acceleration is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 740, 920, 758]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 71, 492, 89]]<|/det|> The table shows values of the variables \(x\) and \(y\). <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 102, 890, 153]]<|/det|>
\(x\)246810
\(y\)7362711003713
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 215, 902, 234]]<|/det|> The relationship between \(x\) and \(y\) is thought to be of the form \(y = A\mathrm{e}^{bx}\), where \(A\) and \(b\) are constants. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 247, 143, 265]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 246, 549, 265]]<|/det|> Transform this relationship into straight line form. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 247, 920, 266]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 348, 143, 367]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 345, 798, 365]]<|/det|> Hence, by plotting a suitable graph, show that the relationship \(y = A\mathrm{e}^{bx}\) is correct. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 346, 920, 365]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 72, 141, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 520, 89]]<|/det|>
Use your graph to find the value of \(A\) and of \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 440, 141, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 440, 455, 459]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 459]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 694, 141, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 693, 435, 712]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 693, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
